name: Food
notes: notes
secondsource: Other International review board or metastudy

name: 0 = no evidence, 1,2 = slight, 3 = conflicting or moderate, 4 = promising, 5 = good, 6 = strong
type: what type of substance is this?
highlight: few studies / trials but positive potential
metric_001: square root of google hits (used to scale the bubbles) - "food + health"
metric_002: 0 can also mean no data on no. of papers in a review
metric_003: square root of Google Scholar hits - "food + health"
notes: every day language
exclude: Show this item in the viz?

name: açaí berry
notes: No human trials. Cell studies show strong anti-oxidant effects - but that's a long way from being "anti-cancer" in humans.

name: açaí berry
notes: Acai berries are widely marketed for weight loss despite no definitive scientific evidence.

name: alfalfa
notes: Showing some potential, especially for cardiovascular health. No evidence as yet.

name: almonds
notes: Almonds consistently lower "bad" (LDL) cholestrol in healthy individuals, and those with high cholesterol and diabetes. (Berryman et al 2011)

name: amaranth
notes: The bulk of the research has been in animal studies.  The Amaranth grain does contain potentially beneficial medicinal compound in varying amounts. Results: inconclusive.

name: amla berry
alternativename: aamla berry, Indian gooseberry, Phyllanthus emblica
subcategory: oxidative stress in people with kidney failure
notes: Patients with uremia (a side effect of kidney failure) benefited slightly from a 4-month amla-berry supplement for 4 months (changed one sign of cell damage in the blood). But no significant differences were observed in liver function, kidney function, diabetic and cardiovascular risk..

name: apples
notes: Beneficial effects on cancer risk, cardiovascular disease, asthma, and Alzheimer's disease. Compounds called "polyphenols" may positively influence on levels of fat in the blood and blood pressure. Some apple varieties may be better than others. However, firm conclusions cannot be drawn.

name: barley
notes: Three grams of the sugars oats & barley (beta-glucans) per day lowers blood total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, and triglycerides. The average reduction in total cholesterol in the studies examined was 0.6 mmol/L.

name: barleygrass juice
notes: No human trials

name: beetroot
notes: In trials, nitrates in beetroot, beetroot-juice and beetroot-enriched bread all lowered blood pressure in the 24 hours after consumption. Some studies show an effect in men, but not women.

name: black tea
notes: Highly conflicting evidence on cancer (some studies suggest benefits, others report no effects). Black tea does contain antioxidants  but green tea has more - and besides the 'take antioxidants' to improve your health theory has largely been disproved. Why not make yourself a nice cup of tea while you think about this?

name: black tea
notes: Based on early research, black tea may reduce stress and help patients feel more relaxed. Of course, high doses of caffeine have been linked to anxiety.

name: blackcurrants
notes: Some of the natural compounds in berries have been linked to delaying the onset of aging. Their antioxidant effects may help human health, but no link has been scientifically proven. Cell studies show anti-cancer effects. But no human evidence.

name: bladderwrack (seaweed)
notes: Appears to have hormonal effects. In a small case-report (not placebo controlled) intake of bladderwrack significantly increased menstrual cycle length (by 5.5-14 days). More and larger studies are needed to establish this. Bladderwrack is a good source of iodine (the mineral needed for thyroid health).

name: bladderwrack and rockweed
notes: Ingesting capsules containing a mix of two brown seaweeds after a high-carb bread snack affected insulin but not glucose levels.

name: blueberries
notes: Some compounds in berries have been linked to delaying the onset of aging. Their antioxidant effects may help human health, but no link has been scientifically proven. Cell studies show anti-cancer effects. No human trials.

name: brazil nuts
notes: Brazil nuts improved the level of fats in the blood of obese adolescents, possibly due to its high level of unsaturated fats and other bioactive substances.

name: broccoli
notes: Eating broccoli, cabbage, cauliflower and other cruciferous vegetables is related to decreased risk of bladder cancer. No effect seen for colorectal cancer.

name: broccoli sprouts
notes: The compound "sulforaphane" found in broccoli sprouts kills the bacterium Helicobacter pylori – a major cause of stomach cancer – after daily intake for 8 weeks.

name: burdock root
notes: Used in traditional Chinese medicine. Contains several compounds that may boost skin blood circulation, improve skin texture and quality and help cure eczema. No human trials yet.

name: butternut squash
notes: No human trials

name: cabbage
notes: Eating broccoli, cabbage, cauliflower and other cruciferous vegetables is related to decreased risk of bladder cancer. No effect seen for colorectal cancer.

name: camu camu
notes: Very high in vitamin C. But a single study of smokers suggests its powerful anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory effects may be due to other substances in the fruit.

name: carob
notes: Lab trials show carob extract can protect human colon cells from DNA damage. But no trials on humans yet.

name: cherries
notes: Cherries are nutritionally rich. In lab and animal studies, show antioxidant and anti-cancer effects. But human studies are needed.

name: chia seeds
notes: May increase omega 3 levels in older women. Weak evidence for cardio effects. No evidence for weight loss.

name: chlorella
notes: Good source of magnesium and GABA (a chemical with a calming effect on the brain). Has slight lowering effect on blood pressure. More research needed.

name: chocolate, dark
notes: 2-18 weeks of dark chocolate slightly (but significantly) reduces blood pressure in those with high blood-pressure. Less effect on those with normal blood pressure.

name: chocolate, dark
notes: People who eat more chocolate have a lower risk of heart disease (by 37%), stroke (29%) and diabetes. But properly controlled trials needed. It could be something other than the chocolate.

name: cinnamon
notes: Some individual studies have suggested cinnamon may lower blood glucose. But overall, cinnamon appears not to affect various factors related to diabetes and heart disease.

name: coconut oil
notes: Replacing other fats with coconut oil when on a diet can enhance weight loss, spare muscle and reduce hunger.

name: coffee
notes: Modestly improves airway function in people with asthma for up to 4 hours. Some trials used caffeine pills rather than coffee.

name: coffee
notes: Women who drink more coffee (not decaf) have a lower depression risk. More research needed on whether caffeine prevents depression.

name: coffee
notes: People who drink more coffee suffer less from diabetes, various cancers, Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. But coffee raises cholesterol and worsens insomnia and some heart problems. Caffeine withdrawal an obvious downside for the addicted. Pregnant and postmenopausal women should avoid drinking too much.

name: coffee
notes: Those with a higher caffeine intake appear have a lower risk of developing Alzheimer's and other dementias. But more research needed to establish causality.

name: cordyceps sinensis
alternativename: ophiocordyceps sinensis, caterpillar fungus, yartsa gunbu, yatsa gunbu, Dōng chóng xià cǎo, bailing
notes: A fungus that grows on moth larvae – yum. Regular supplementation improves some aspects of kidney health among transplant patients or those with kidney disease.

name: cranberry products
notes: Cranberry juice doesn't prevent painful urinary tract infections. In trials many people stopped drinking it. Cranberry tablets and capsules also ineffective.

name: dandelion
notes: Dandelion soup + penicillin more effective for tonsilitis than penicillin alone.

name: dulse
notes: A potential source of antioxidants. Very high in potassium - one woman with kidney problems was hospitalized after eating dulse. No human trials yet.

name: ecklonia cava seaweed
notes: 12 weeks of either seaweed or extract reduces body weight and fat, and improves various cardio measures including cholesterol. Polyphenols may be active compounds. Larger studies needed.

name: ecklonia cava seaweed
notes: A high dose of a polyphenol extract from seaweed for 12 weeks lowered blood pressure. A lower dose did not.

name: eggs
notes: Can reduce hunger, reduce food intake and regulate blood glucose and insulin levels for up to 36 hours. Particularly effective if eaten for breakfast.

name: eggs
notes: 6 eggs a week may improve eye health. Eggs contain carotenoid compounds needed for good vision.

name: eggs
subcategory: blood sugar and cardio risk factors in diabetes
notes: In diabetics, a high protein diet with eggs lowers blood pressure, blood sugar and improves other aspects of cardio health better than the same diet without eggs. The cholesterol issue: eggs do raise cholesterol in a small number of people, but not the majority.

name: elderberry
notes: An elderberry extract called Sambucol may be good for viral influenza. But more rigorous studies are needed.

name: elderberry
notes: Low doses of an elderberry extract had a minor antioxidant and cholesterol lowering effect.

name: elk velvet antler
notes: Ineffective. Two studies so far show no improvements in joint pain and swelling and other arthritis symptoms after taking velvet antler compared to placebo.

name: fish oil / omega 3
notes: Omega 3 fats are found in oily fish and some vegetable oils. Not clear whether omega 3 intake has any effect on heart attack, stroke or cancer risk, or risk of death from any cause. But potent at lowering triglycerides (which increase cardio disease risk) among people with high levels.

name: fish oil / omega 3
notes: People with advanced cancer benefit from omega 3 supplements. Omega 3 increases weight and appetite, improves quality of life and health after surgery. More than 1.5 grams per day for at least 8 weeks recommended.

name: fish oil / omega 3
notes: Changing your diet to include more fish oil does not improve asthma.

name: fish oil / omega 3
notes: DHA (a kind of omega 3 fatty acid) may or may not improve aspects of cognitive function among children.

name: fish oil / omega 3
notes: No benefit on cognitive function among healthy older people without dementia. But DHA supplements may improve learning and memory among people already showing signs of age-related cognitive decline.

name: fish oil / omega 3
notes: People who consume the most fish oil seem to have a lower risk of developing colorectal cancer (around 12-34% lower than those who consume the least). But more research needed to establish whether the link is causal.

name: flax seeds
notes: Contain soluble fiber and may have a laxative effect.

name: flax seeds
notes: In a single study, flaxseed muffins reduced some markers of cancer cell death in breast cancer patients. It has the potential to reduce tumor growth - but more and larger studies needed.

name: fruit & veg
notes: Contrary to popular belief, eating fruit and vegetables has little effect on overall cancer risk. But specific groups of vegetables may protect against particular cancer types.

name: garlic
notes: Lowers blood pressure, especially in people with high blood pressure.

name: garlic
notes: Aged garlic extract increased natural killer cell activity but did not improve quality of life in patients with advanced gastric cancer.

name: garlic
notes: Eating more garlic is associated with lower cancer risk, especially for stomach and intestinal cancers. However, the link may or may not be causal. More research needed.

name: garlic
notes: Insufficient evidence from clinical trials on whether garlic can prevent or treat colds. Much evidence poor quality.

name: ginger
notes: Ginger products may be helpful to women, but evidence of effectiveness limited and not consistent.

name: goji berry
notes: High in antioxidants needed for good vision. Goji supplements for 90 days increase blood levels of these antioxidants and improves some measures of eye health. More trials needed.

name: goji berry
notes: Used in traditional Chinese medicine. Clinical studies lacking.

name: grapefruit
notes: May provide small boost to weight loss when eaten before meals. Fruit or juice had negligible effect on blood pressure and cholesterol in a single study.

name: grapes
notes: Emerging evidence of protective effect against cardiovascular disease. Perhaps due to polyphenols.

name: green coffee beans
notes: Green (unroasted) coffee appears to lower blood pressure while ordinary roasted coffee does not. The more green coffee is drunk, the larger the effect. Why? The BP-lowering effects of beneficial acids in green coffee seem to be inhibited by other compounds produced during the roasting process.

name: green tea
notes: Conflicting evidence on whether it reduces cancer risk. But appears to be safe to drink moderately and regularly.

name: green tea
notes: High green tea consumption associated with very slightly lower total cholesterol among middle-aged Japanese people. Green tea extract enriched with a polyphenol compound called theaflavin may lower total cholesterol and 'bad' cholesterol.

name: hawthorn
notes: Hawthorn extract made from dried hawthorn improved heart function and symptoms of heart failure in patients with chronic heart failure. Appears beneficial when used in on top of existing treatment.

name: hawthorn
notes: A small number of studies suggest hawthorn extract may modestly lower blood pressure.

name: hemp seeds
notes: Questions remain regarding the cardiovascular effects of hemp seed.

name: honey
notes: Honey may lower cholesterol and positively affect other cardio risk factors. Also reduces markers of inflammation during cycle training.

name: honey
notes: May be better at relieving coughs than nothing. But not better than standard cough suppressant drugs. No strong evidence for or against use. Trials at high risk of bias.

name: honey
notes: Kills infections when applied directly to wounds. Also promotes healing when eaten by killing bacteria and controlling inflammation. New Zealand manuka honey the best.

name: horsetail
alternativename: Equisetum arvense, shavegrass, common horsetail, field horsetail, tsukushi
notes: Contains silicon, a mineral needed for bone health. Menopausal women treated with dried extract improved bone density, especially when horsetail taken with calcium.

name: kimchi
notes: A Korean fermented vegetable condiment. One trial showed fermented kimchi better than fresh kimchi at lowering blood pressure, blood sugar, cholesterol and body fat in overweight people. More trials needed.

name: krill oil
notes: Might ease premenstrual cramps and emotional symptoms.

name: krill oil
notes: One study showed 300mg a day appeared to reduce inflammation and soothe arthritis symptoms after 7 days. More studies needed.

name: leek
notes: High consumption of allium vegetables (onions, leeks, garlic) apparently linked to reduced stomach cancer risk. Further studies needed to rule out other factors.

name: lemon
notes: Eating citrus fruit appears to decrease stomach, perhaps pancreatic, but not prostate cancer risk.

name: longan fruit
alternativename: Dimocarpus longan, Dragon Eyes, Euphoria Longan
notes: Traditionally used as a tonic and treatment for forgetfulness, insomnia, or palpitations caused by fright. Lab and animal studies it may protect brain cells and improve cognition. One human trial found longan plus other ingredients was effective for weight loss.

name: mushrooms
notes: Several anti-cancer drugs are derived from mushroom compounds. But no scientific basis for use of mushrooms or mushroom extracts themselves in treatment.

name: nattō
notes: High in vitamin K2, which may play a role in bone formation. Appears to increase blood levels of K2 and a bone-building protein called osteocalcin. Improves some markers of bone health but not others.

name: nattō
notes: May lower blood sugar and insulin levels after a meal.

name: nettles
notes: A potentially effective treatment for lower urinary tract symptoms caused by prostate problems in older men. Effective for moderate and severe symptoms. No negative side effects.

name: oats
notes: Three grams of the sugars oats & barley (beta-glucans) per day lowers blood total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, and triglycerides. The average reduction in total cholesterol in the studies examined was 0.6 mmol/L.

name: oily fish
notes: People consuming the most fish, especially oily fish, at a lower risk of colorectal cancer than those consuming the least. But more clinical trials needed.

name: olive oil
notes: Olive oil is associated with a wide range of anti-artery-hardening effects. Olive oil-rich diets can be a useful tool against risk factors for cardiovascular disease.

name: oranges
notes: Eating citrus fruit appears to decrease stomach, perhaps pancreatic, but not prostate cancer risk.

name: oysters
notes: Oysters are an excellent source of zinc. Severe zinc deficiency can cause impotence. But no evidence that eating oysters boosts sex drive.

name: papaya
notes: Rich in lycopene. Intake of lycopene-rich foods associated with reduced risk of several cancers, notably prostate cancer. But few clinical trials.

name: parsley
notes: May decrease damage to blood proteins. Apigenin, a flavanoid found most abundantly in parsley and camomile flowers, shows anti-cancer effects in the lab. No human trials on cancer as yet.

name: peppermint oil
notes: Probably an effective treatment for irritable bowel syndrome. In trials, rated symptoms improved by 57% on average.

name: peppers
notes: People who eat more peppers appear to lower their Parkinson's risk. The reason? Nicotine. Pepper plants come from the same family as tobacco. Protective effects strongest for non-smokers.

name: pineapple
notes: A compound in pineapple called bromelain mght reduce swelling and pain after injury or surgery.

name: pomegranate
notes: Juice or extract may protect against diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and some cancers.

name: pomegranate juice
notes: One study showed a marginal effect of pomegranate juice on erectile dysfunction. But don't all rush at once: the results weren't quite statistically significant.

name: prickly pear cactus
notes: Traditionally consumed as a vegetable. May lower blood sugar and improve metabolic syndrome (a combination of factors including being fat and having high blood pressure that increase cardiovascular disease risk).

name: prickly pear cactus
notes: Appears to affect inflammation an might reduce hangover symptoms. Improved nausea, dry mouth and appetite in a trial of the hungover. Cut risk of a severe hangover in half.

name: probiotics
notes: Associated with 42% lower risk of diarrhoea caused by antibiotics. Lactobacillus strains mostly used in trials. More research needed to see which strains most effective.

name: prunes
notes: Compounds in prunes called phenols show beneficial effects on cholesterol in the lab, so might protect against heart disease and cancer. No human studies yet.

name: prunes
notes: Better than a standard remedy (psyllium husk) at treating mild to moderate constipation.

name: pu-erh tea
notes: A fermented dark Chinese tea. Possibly effective as a weight loss aid. More human studies needed.

name: pulses
notes: Foods high in soluble fibre like oats, beans and pulses can help lower cholesterol. Appears to reduce blood pressure, blood sugar, diabetes and obesity risk. So may also protect against cardiovascular disease.

name: pumpkin seeds
notes: Pumpkin seeds contain high-levels of 'squalene', an important dietary cancer preventive.

name: quinoa
notes: High nutritional value but few trials.

name: red wine
notes: Moderate drinking of red wine reduces cardiovascular risk, including artery-thickening (atherosclerosis) and heart disease (ischemic). Obviously, there are additional risks involved in drinking alcohol.

name: reishi mushroom
notes: Analysis of trials did not find sufficient evidence to justify the use of Reishi as a first-line cancer treatment. However, it could be used to boost anti-tumour responses and immune system.

name: rockweed
alternativename: Ascophyllum nodosum, kelp (one of many species), egg wrack
notes: Very preliminary evidence for reducing appetite.

name: sage
notes: Improvement in memory, attention, mood and anxiety levels consistently seen in studies.

name: sage
notes: Daily use may reduce hormonal hot flushes in both women and men. Combining with alfalfa may increase the effect.

name: soy isoflavones
notes: Can reduce the frequency and severity of hot flushes.

name: strawberries
notes: Broad benefits noticed on cardiovascular and neurological health.

name: sweet potato
notes: Insufficient evidence that sweet potatoes are useful for type 2 diabetes sufferers.

name: tomatoes
notes: Tomatoes are high in lycopene. No robust evidence showing any effect on prostate cancer.

name: turmeric
notes: Curcumin, found in turmeric, is a potential treatment for ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, colonic cancer and IBS. But difficult for body to absorb in its natural form.

name: turmeric
notes: Used medicinally in China and India for thousands of years. Active ingredient, curcumin, a strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory. Clinical studies promising but more needed. Could treat cancer and other chronic diseases. Hard to absorb, but could form basis for new drugs.

name: wholegrains
notes: A high intake of whole-grain foods cereal fibre (rice, wheat, corn, rye, oat & barley) is linked to a lower risk of types 2 diabetes.

name: yoghurt, live
notes: Probiotics show a lot of promise. Unfortunately, marketing and popularity has outpaced the research. So a lot of the health claims are not backed up and many are false. We're planning a visualisation clarifying probiotics very soon.
